title.narrative: Weldy Lamont Rural Electrification Project, through Weldy Lamont Associates, Inc.

description.narrative: A USTDA de minimis training grant is supporting a bid by the U.S. company Weldy Lamont Associates, Inc. to provide equipment and services to expand energy access in Senegal through grid extension and off-grid renewable solutions. The proposed grant would be provided to the Senegalese Ministry of Energy. The training supported by this grant would help increase Senegal's capacity to implement, operate and maintain the technology and systems required to expand energy access to rural communities in Senegal.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Battery Storage for Grid-Resiliency, through Det Norske Veritas Group

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study for Lekela Energie Stockage S.A.U., a privatelyowned company in Senegal, to fund a feasibility study (Study) to provide the technical, economic, and environmental analysis necessary to implement and operate a grid-scale battery electric storage system to manage variable renewable energy generation in Senegal (Project). The Project is anticipated to deploy at least 60 megawatt hours of grid-tied battery storage capacity. The Study would be competed among U.S. firms on the USTDA website and publicized via Sam.gov as well as highlighted through USTDA and Power Africa social media and marketing platforms

title.narrative: Gas Pipeline Network, through Advisian Group, LLC

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study, including a preliminary front-end engineering design, to support the development of Senegals first major domestic onshore gas pipeline (Project). The Project is expected to be the backbone of Senegals domestic gas sector, enabling the development of a mid- and downstream gas sector in Senegal and significantly reducing the cost of power generation. The Project will support the U.S. Governments Electrify Africa Act and Power and Prosper Africa Initiatives, as well as USTDAs U.S. Gas Infrastructure Exports Initiative.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

The Project is expected to be the backbone of Senegals domestic gas sector, enabling the development of a mid- and downstream gas sector in Senegal and significantly reducing the cost of power generation. The Project will support the U.S. Governments Electrify Africa Act and Power and Prosper Africa Initiatives, as well as USTDAs U.S. Gas Infrastructure Exports Initiative. The Grantee is Fonds Souverain dInvestissements Stratgiques (FONSIS).

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Hospitals and Mobile Healthcare Trailers Public Private Partnership Project, through Enterprise - United States Unknown

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study for the Senegalese Ministry of Economy, Planning and Cooperation ("MEPC") to analyze options for the development of a public private partnership ("PPP") model to implement four hospitals and approximately three to five mobile healthcare trailers in Senegal. This feasibility study will help MEPC, as well as the Ministry of Health and Social Affairs, determine the best PPP approach to developing important healthcare infrastructure in the country.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - Hospitals and Mobile Healthcare Trailers Public Private Partnership Project, through Anadach Consulting Group, LLC

description.narrative: This grant funds a feasibility study for the Senegalese Ministry of Economy, Planning and Cooperation ("MEPC") to analyze options for the development of a public private partnership ("PPP") model to implement four hospitals and approximately three to five mobile healthcare trailers in Senegal. This feasibility study will help MEPC, as well as the Ministry of Health and Social Affairs, determine the best PPP approach to developing important healthcare infrastructure in the country.

title.narrative: Feasibility Study - CORNICHE WEST WASTEWATER TREATMENT, through Government of Senegal

description.narrative: This Feasibility Study grant of $418,908 is aimed at the implementation of wastewater collection and treatment facilities for the Corniche West sector in the City of Dakar. Implementing the results of this study and improving sanitation conditions in the City of Dakar is a priority for the grantee, the Office Nationale de l'Assainissement du Senegal ("ONAS"). The study would also encourage U.S. firms to enter the steadily growing environmental sector market in West Africa.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

title.narrative: Solar Minigrid Advanced Metering and Monitoring, through MRIGlobal

description.narrative: This grant to Energie Rurale Africaine S.A. funds technical assistance for the implementation and operation of solar minigrids in 31 villages in the regions of Kaffrine-Tamabacouda-Kedougou, Senegal. This will help increase energy access in Senegal and create economic growth opportunities for over 3,500 households. The technical assistance also includes piloting and field-testing U.S. advanced metering, payment collection, and remote monitoring technology. MRIGlobal (Kansas City, MO) is the sole source contractor implementing the technical assistance.

person-name.narrative: Amy Swers and Liz Sutton; Ryan Boles

sector.narrative: Solar energy for isolated grids and standalone systems
